Revisiting and Improving Scoring Fusion for Spoofing-aware Speaker Verification Using Compositional Data Analysis

Abstract

Fusing outputs from automatic speaker verification (ASV) and spoofing countermeasure (CM) is expected to make an integrated system robust to zero-effort imposters and synthesized spoofing attacks. Many score-level fusion methods have been proposed, but many remain heuristic. This paper revisits score-level fusion using tools from decision theory and presents three main findings. First, fusion by summing the ASV and CM scores can be interpreted on the basis of compositional data analysis, and score calibration before fusion is essential. Second, the interpretation leads to an improved fusion method that linearly combines the log-likelihood ratios of ASV and CM. However, as the third finding reveals, this linear combination is inferior to a non-linear one in making optimal decisions. The outcomes of these findings, namely, the score calibration before fusion, improved linear fusion, and better non-linear fusion, were found to be effective on the SASV challenge database.

keywords:
speaker verification, anti-spoofing, fusion, log-likelihood ratio, ternary classification

1 Introduction

Automatic speaker verification (ASV) systems are vulnerable to spoofed synthetic speech data that clone the target speakersâ€™ voices [1]. By combining ASV and spoofing countermeasure (CM), which ideally should reject any spoofed data, we expect to be able to construct a spoofing-aware ASV (SASV) system that only accepts speech data from real (bona fide) humans who match the target speakerâ€™s identity.

An SASV system can be a cascade of ASV and CM sub-systems [2]. The ASV and CM make separate binary decisions, and the input is accepted if it is accepted by both sub-systems. Another design used by many SASV systems is to produce one score and make one binary decision. An example SASV system using score-level fusion (baseline B1 of the SASV challenge [5]) is illustrated in Fig.Â 1. Its ASV sub-system extracts embeddings from ğ’™(p)superscriptğ’™ğ‘\bm{x}^{(p)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’™(r)superscriptğ’™ğ‘Ÿ\bm{x}^{(r)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and computes their cosine similarity as sasvsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which indicates the degree that ğ’™(p)superscriptğ’™ğ‘\bm{x}^{(p)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’™(r)superscriptğ’™ğ‘Ÿ\bm{x}^{(r)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT match in terms of speaker identity. The CM sub-system extracts an embedding from ğ’™(p)superscriptğ’™ğ‘\bm{x}^{(p)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and produces a score scmâˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘ cmâ„s_{\text{cm}}\in\mathbb{R}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R using a neural network. Hence, it is intuitively reasonable to fuse the scores by ssasv=sasv+scmsubscriptğ‘ sasvsubscriptğ‘ asvsubscriptğ‘ cms_{\text{sasv}}=s_{\text{asv}}+s_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

More advanced fusion functions have been proposed in the SASV and other biometrics fields [7, 2]. Although most are intuitively reasonable, for example, normalizing the numeric range of sasvsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscriptğ‘ cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT before summation [5], the link between practice and theory is not always clear. Therefore, the implicit assumptions, link to optimal decisions, and room for improvement remain elusive.

Starting from the summation of the ASV and CM scores, we scrutinize the score fusion using tools from decision theory. After reformulating SASV as a classification task that involves three data classes but requires a binary decision, we interpret SASV scoring from the perspective of compositional data analysis and show that the summation of sasvsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscriptğ‘ cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a reasonable choice if the ASV and CM scores are proper log-likelihood ratios (LLRs). Hence, the interpretation indicates that score calibration before fusion is beneficial. The interpretation also leads to an improved fusion method that uses probabilistic models to compute LLRs for summation. Finally, the summation-based fusion is analyzed from the perspective of optimal decision policy and found to be theoretically inferior to a non-linear fusion method.

The above interpretations of SASV have not been presented as far as the authors are aware. They differ from one existing study that treats {sasv,scm}subscriptğ‘ asvsubscriptğ‘ cm\{s_{\text{asv}},s_{\text{cm}}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } as posterior probabilities [8]. Experiments were conducted on the SASV challenge database [5]. The calibration before fusion was found to be effective, especially for linear fusion by summation. The linear and non-linear fusion of LLRs outperformed baselines, and the latter outperformed the systems fusing posterior probabilities [8]. The results are reproducible. 111Code site: https://github.com/nii-yamagishilab/SpeechSPC-mini.

2.2 Interpreting SASV using compositional data analysis

2.5 Fusion method 3: nonlinear fusion of LLRs

The interpretation so far leads to the simple form of score fusion in Eqs.Â (5) and (6). Importantly, however, it also reveals a major limitation for making decisions. Inequality.Â (7) is a necessary but not sufficient condition to achieve Ineq.Â (9). For example, a sample with [P(H|ğ—Œğ—‰ğ–¿ğ’™),P(H|ğ—‡ğ—ˆğ—‡.ğ–»ğ–¿ğ’™),P(H|ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹.ğ–»ğ–¿ğ’™)]=[0.05,0.65,0.3][P({H}{}_{\mathsf{spf}{}}|\bm{x}),P({H}{}_{\mathsf{non.bf}{}}|\bm{x}),P({H}{}_% {\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}|\bm{x})]=[0.05,0.65,0.3][ italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) , italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) , italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) ] = [ 0.05 , 0.65 , 0.3 ] will be rejected by Ineq.Â (9) but falsely accepted by (7). The overall decision cost cannot be lower than that based on the optimal decision policy in Ineq.Â (9) (or (10)), given that we know the true LLRs and priors.

To support the above argument, we generated ASV and CM scores using Gaussian distributions and a uniform prior, which enables us to compute the true LLRs and compared the linear and non-linear decision boundaries. As Fig.Â 3 indicates, the non-linear one based on Ineq.Â (10) leads to a lower decision cost, particularly, a lower false acceptance rate. Note that, Ineqs.Â (8) and (10) are agnostic to the data distributions, and we use Gaussians in simulation only for convenience.

On the basis of Ineq.Â (10), we define a new fusion method

ssasv=âˆ’logâ¡[(1âˆ’Ï)â¢eâˆ’ğ—…ğ—…ğ—‹ğ—‡ğ—ˆğ—‡.ğ–»ğ–¿ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹.ğ–»ğ–¿â¢(ğ’”)+Ïâ¢eâˆ’ğ—…ğ—…ğ—‹ğ—Œğ—‰ğ–¿ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹.ğ–»ğ–¿â¢(ğ’”)].subscriptğ‘ sasv1ğœŒsuperscriptğ‘’subscriptsuperscriptğ—…ğ—…ğ—‹formulae-sequenceğ—ğ–ºğ—‹ğ–»ğ–¿formulae-sequenceğ—‡ğ—ˆğ—‡ğ–»ğ–¿ğ’”ğœŒsuperscriptğ‘’subscriptsuperscriptğ—…ğ—…ğ—‹formulae-sequenceğ—ğ–ºğ—‹ğ–»ğ–¿ğ—Œğ—‰ğ–¿ğ’”s_{\text{sasv}}=-\log\big{[}(1-\rho)e^{-\mathsf{llr}^{\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}_{% \mathsf{non.bf}}(\bm{s})}+\rho e^{-\mathsf{llr}^{\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}_{\mathsf{% spf}{}}(\bm{s})}\big{]}.italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - roman_log [ ( 1 - italic_Ï ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - sansserif_llr start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Ï italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - sansserif_llr start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] . (11)

The usage is similar to that in Sec.Â 2.4, but we plug the LLRs into Eq.Â (11). Unfortunately, the prior-dependent ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï cannot be decoupled from the LLRs, and it needs to be decided, for example, by grid search on a development set. The green solid line in Fig.Â 3 shows the decision boundary when ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï is computed from different priors. It performs reasonably well.

As a special case, if each pâ¢(ğ’”;ğœ½)ğ‘ğ’”ğœ½p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_Î¸ ) is implemented as a Gaussian distribution, Eq.Â (11) turns out to be equivalent to the so-called Gaussian back-end fusion [21, Eq.(1)]. The link between Gaussian back-end fusion and the optimal decision has not been shown before as far as the authors are aware. Detailed proof is available on the code site (see link on page 1).

3 Experiments

We verified the effectiveness of the three fusion methods on the SASV challenge dataset [5] and the official training, development, and evaluation splits.

3.1 Model recipe and evaluation metrics

All eight experimental systems were based on the open-sourced SASV challenge baseline B1 (Fig.Â 1) and used the pre-trained ECAPA-TDNN-based ASV [22] and AASIST-based CM [23] embedding extractors, which were provided by the challenge organizers. The differences in the systems are

  • â€¢

    B1 is a replicate of SASV B1. The ASV branch requires no training, and the neural network in the CM branch is trained using binary cross-entropy given scmsubscriptğ‘ cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the labels for CM. The SASV score is computed by ssasv=scm+sasvsubscriptğ‘ sasvsubscriptğ‘ cmsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{sasv}}=s_{\text{cm}}+s_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • â€¢

    L2 is similar to B1 but uses Eq.Â (6) for score fusion. Each pâ¢(ğ’”;ğœ½)ğ‘ğ’”ğœ½p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_Î¸ ) is a Gaussian with a full covariance matrix.

  • â€¢

    L3 follows L2 but uses Eq.Â (11) for score fusion.

  • â€¢

    B1c, L2c, and L3c are variants of B1, L2, and L3, respectively, but calibrated scores or LLRs before fusion. The calibration function is fâ¢(x)=aâ¢x+bğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘f(x)=ax+bitalic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_a italic_x + italic_b.

They interpret scores as posterior probabilities and fuse by ssasv=Ïƒâ¢(scm)+sasvsubscriptğ‘ sasvğœsubscriptğ‘ cmsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{sasv}}=\sigma(s_{\text{cm}})+s_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ssasv=Ïƒâ¢(scm)Ã—Ïƒâ¢(sasv)subscriptğ‘ sasvğœsubscriptğ‘ cmğœsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{sasv}}=\sigma(s_{\text{cm}})\times\sigma(s_{\text{asv}})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) Ã— italic_Ïƒ ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), respectively [24]. All systems have about 82.5 k trainable parameters in the the neural network for CM, which has three hidden layers with 258, 128, and 64 neurons, respectively. All layers used a leaky ReLU activation with a negative slope value of 0.3. All systems were trained on a Tesla V100 card using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 5Ã—10âˆ’55superscript1055\times 10^{-5}5 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, batch size of 24, and weight decay with a coefficient of 1Ã—10âˆ’31superscript1031\times 10^{-3}1 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The maximum number of training epochs was 10, and the checkpoint with the best CM EER on the development set was used for evaluation. The implementation was done using SpeechBrain [25], and the training took less than one day per system.

The SASV-EER [5] was used to gauge the discrimination power of ssasvsubscriptğ‘ sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The log-likelihood-ratio cost CllrCllr\mathrm{Cllr}roman_Cllr [26] was also computed and decomposed into CllrminsubscriptCllrmin\mathrm{Cllr}_{\text{min}}roman_Cllr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and CllrcalibsubscriptCllrcalib\mathrm{Cllr}_{\text{calib}}roman_Cllr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT calib end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to measure the discrimination and calibration performance of ssasvsubscriptğ‘ sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The t-EER [6] was computed given {sasv,scm}subscriptğ‘ asvsubscriptğ‘ cm\{s_{\text{asv}},s_{\text{cm}}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } or the LLRs. Each system was trained and evaluated for six rounds, where each round used a different seed to randomly initialize the neural network in the CM sub-system. The averaged results are listed in TableÂ 1. The confidence interval of SASV-EER was using the Interspeech official toolkit with the default setting.

3.2 Results

Calibration before fusion was useful: As reported in the original paper [5], B1 achieved an SASV-EER of around 20%. As Fig.Â 4(a) shows, due to the large difference in the dynamic ranges of ASV and CM scores, the latter dominated the fused SASV score. The values of CllrCllr\mathrm{Cllr}roman_Cllr and CllrcalibsubscriptCllrcalib\mathrm{Cllr}_{\text{calib}}roman_Cllr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT calib end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were higher than 1 bit, indicating that the SASV scores were not useful for making decisions. By calibrating sasvsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscriptğ‘ cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT before fusion, B1c reduced the SASV EER to 2.73%, and CllrCllr\mathrm{Cllr}roman_Cllr-based metrics also improved. From Fig.Â 4(b), we can observe that the distribution of sasvsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was â€˜stretched outâ€™, and the fused ssasvsubscriptğ‘ sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT better separated the three classes of data.

When fusing LLRs, the system pairs {L2, L2c} and {L3, L3c} showed that the gain of the calibration was diminishing. This is understandable because the dynamic range of ASV and CM scores are handled by the covariance matrix of pâ¢(ğ’”;ğœ½)ğ‘ğ’”ğœ½p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_Î¸ ). However, calibrating before fusion was still helpful, especially in the case of linear fusion in Eq.Â (6). Compared with L2, L2câ€™s EER was reduced to 1.56%, and its CllrCllr\mathrm{Cllr}roman_Cllr was only 0.14 bits.

Non-linear fusion of LLRs was better: Rather than fusing the ASV and CM scores, L2, L3, and their variants fused the estimated LLRs. The nonlinear fusion of LLRs in L3c led to the best SASV-EER in our experiments. The difference between L3c and L2c was small, possibly because the test data set of the SASV challenge can be well separated using a linear decision boundary in the space of LLRs, as Fig.Â 4(c) and (d) show.

Compared with B1v2 and Post, which treat the ASV and CM scores as posterior probabilities, L2c, L3, and L3c performed similarly or better in terms of SASV-EER, and their CllrcalibsubscriptCllrcalib\mathrm{Cllr}_{\text{calib}}roman_Cllr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT calib end_POSTSUBSCRIPTs were much lower. The results suggest that the fusion methods based on compositional data analysis are also practically useful.

Finally, the t-EER measures the discrimination power of {sasv,scm}subscriptğ‘ asvsubscriptğ‘ cm\{s_{\text{asv}},s_{\text{cm}}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } or LLRs and is agnostic to their calibration and fusion. Hence, the t-EERs of B1 and B1c are the same. Similarly, the four systems fusing LLRs have the same t-EER. It was observed that using the LLRs led to a lower t-EER than raw or sigmoid-transformed sasvsubscriptğ‘ asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscriptğ‘ cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is evidence to encourage the sub-systems to produce LLRs.

4 Conclusions

This paper presented an alternative interpretation of SASV score fusion based on compositional data analysis. We suggested practices and improved fusion methods that may have been ignored or used ad hoc. First, the calibration of scores or LLRs before fusion was found to be helpful, especially when linearly fusing raw scores or LLRs. Second, rather than fusing raw scores, estimating and fusing LLRs turned out to be better in experiments. Third, the linear fusion of LLRs was found to be inferior to the non-linear one in both analysis and experiments. What is presented in this paper is by no means the only way to interpret SASV fusion, thus is expected to foster other studies.

This is the optimal decision policy for ASV as a typical binary classification task [27, (2.33)].

Note that the LLRs are on the left hand side, while the priors (and decision costs) are on the right hand side. Because the LLRs are decoupled from the priors, the system can be designed to produce the LLRs without considering the priors. It is the user, who deploys the system into an application, assign the decision costs, asserted priors, and accordingly the decision threshold. The decoupled LLRs and priors are preferred in a forensic context [28, 27]. A similar decision policy can be derived when Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1italic_Ï = 1, i.e., CM without ASV.

Unfortunately, when Ïâˆˆ(0,1)ğœŒ01\rho\in(0,1)italic_Ï âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), the LLRs and priors cannot be decoupled. The ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï is needed to compute the score, and the SASV system designer has to estimate the value of the ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï, for example, on the basis of the statistics from the development data. In our experiment, ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï was found through grid search by minimizing the decision risks on the development data.

A.2.2 Link to the sub-optimal decision policy

A.3 Comparing with ternary classification

In Sec.A.1, we defined SASV as a classification task with two actions but three data classes. We may compare it with a ternary classification task. A.4 On spoofed sample

A spoofed sample should be rejected by SASV regardless of whether it sounds like the target speaker. If the spoofed probe is forged by an attacker (i.e., biometric imposters in ISO/IEC 30107), it is supposed to sound like the target speakerâ€™s voice; however, the algorithm to create the spoofed probe may not be good enough to mimic the voice. Hence, the spoofed sample should be rejected regardless of its similarity to the target speakerâ€™s voice.

Suppose the â€˜spoofedâ€™ sample is created by an authentic user who wants to make it less similar to their own voice (i.e., biometric concealers). In that case, this application is considered more relevant to voice anonymization [29] rather than SASV. Of course, an SASV system should also reject the â€˜spoofedâ€™ sample since it intended use is to conceal the speakerâ€™s identity.
